awd_titl_txt: A new method for fabricating low-cost, high-performance waveguides, lasers and modulators in photonic integrated circuits for optical communication networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: A new method for fabricating low-cost, high-performance waveguides, lasers and modulators in photonic integrated circuits for optical communication networks.

The integration of multiple lightwave devices such as lasers and optical modulators into a complex, highly functional configuration on a single chip, known as a photonic integrated circuit (PIC), can dramatically reduce the cost of high-speed optical networking systems supporting the internet and telecommunications, akin to advances in electronics and computing offered by silicon integrated circuits.  However, current integration technologies require expensive crystal regrowth processes, face fundamental speed limitations due to the physical properties of the materials now in use, and use electron beam lithography methods (not scalable to mass manufacturing) in order to achieve the small waveguide dimensions needed for optimal performance.  This project supports research on a new low-cost waveguide fabrication method that addresses each of these current shortfalls which promises to significantly enhance the integration level and performance of modulators and lasers for the advanced photonic integrated circuits of the future.  Such PICs will enable lower cost optical communications systems and increase the deployment of broadband internet to underserved population areas.

The specific goals of this research are to develop a unique, new selective waveguide core oxidation process for the AlInGaAs/InP material system used for telecommunication-wavelength photonic devices.  A novel oxygen-enhanced wet thermal oxidation process will be optimized for this new material system and the benefits of the resulting low-refractive-index, low dielectric-constant, insulating, interface-passivating, and roughness-smoothing buried oxide layer fully exploited for the fabrication of high-speed electro-absorption modulator (EAM) and laser devices.  The process allows the overall waveguide core width to be reduced to single-mode dimensions without the need for e-beam lithography. The low dielectric constant offers reduced parasitic capacitance and strong optical confinement without incurring increased contact resistance, thus reducing the overall RC time constant to achieve high modulation speed devices.  The oxide promises to simultaneously dramatically reduce interface roughness and waveguide scattering loss and remediate dry-etch ion damage. The resulting high-index-contrast waveguide structure enables InP-based 1.3 and 1.55 micron telecomm wavelength devices with stable optical spatial mode confinement that can be aggressively curved with low bend loss for optical signal routing and on-chip lasers suitable for densely-packed photonic integrated circuits.  

Research methods to be used include optimization of oxidation system gas flow dynamics to enhance process control and oxide uniformity; characterization and optimization of oxide insulating properties, refractive index, and thermal conductivity; time-resolved photoluminescence to characterize oxide-semiconductor interface quality; precision angle polishing and focused ion beam milling for inspection of buried-oxide interface roughness; and swept-laser Fabry-Perot transmission resonance waveguide loss measurements.  Three targeted oxide-confined AlInGaAs/InP device applications will be explored in collaboration with the Tyndall National Institute in Cork, Ireland: high-speed traveling-wave electro-absorption modulators; high-speed directly-modulated lasers; and compact, curved-resonator on-chip integrated lasers exploiting the low-bend loss properties of the proposed unique oxide-confined waveguiding structure.

por.por_cntn:
Recent advances in III-V compound semiconductor oxidation process technology were employed to develop a new method for the selective lateral oxidation of the light-confining core layer embedded between non-oxidizing InP cladding layers in ridge waveguides for InP-based quantum well heterostructure photonic devices operating at optical fiber communication wavelengths.  Through the use of a precisely controlled and optimized mixed oxygen/water vapor oxidizing ambient and careful overpressure control via the proper use of an ultrathin protective atomic layer deposition (ALD) dielectric layer to suppress thermal dissociation, a high quality, uniform, controlled-thickness buried oxide was grown inward to the depth of ~1 µm from the sidewalls of a deep-etched ridge structure within the AlInGaAs core region to realize a high optical confinement, low-loss single-mode waveguide without the need for conventionally used epitaxial regrowth.  These new waveguides promise to find use in high speed electro-absorption modulators (EAMs) based on the quantum-confined Stark effect; high-speed directly-modulated, high temperature tolerant multiple quantum well lasers; and low-loss curved waveguides for the fabrication of on-chip lasers and other next generation photonic integrated circuit components.  

This work is enabled through a unique, oxygen-enhanced wet thermal oxidation process for AlInGaAs layers lattice matched to InP.  The oxidation proceeds with reasonably fast but readily controllable growth rates and at sufficiently low temperatures to avoid degradation to the semiconductor crystal through thermal dissociation.  When placed between non-oxidizing InP, a suitably thick buried oxide can be selectively grown within only the waveguide core region to enhance the optical mode confinement.  Scattering loss, which can be especially problematic and performance limiting to a high-index-contrast, high-confinement waveguide, is controlled, as the selective oxide growth provides the significant structural advantage of smoothing away the etched sidewall roughness below the limits of even well-optimized lithography and etch processes. The method enables the fabrication of a high-confinement single mode waveguide with dimensions below the limits imposed by the tolerances of standard optical lithography.  The buried sidewall oxide also provides the unique advantage of achieving reduced capacitance (by virtue of the oxide’s much lower dielectric constant) while its growth in an undercut fashion from a larger width ridge preserves a large contact area for low contact resistance.  This unique combination of low-capacitance and low electrical contact resistance yields a reduced RC time constant structure particularly suited for the fabrication of high-speed EAM or laser devices.  In addition to higher modulation speeds, the high-index contrast and strong mode confinement achieved offers improved laser mode stability and the ability to fabricate low bend loss curved waveguide structures for a wide range of photonic integration applications.

In parallel to developing these new methods applicable to the challenging to process InP based alloys, we further refined and optimized the processing of oxide-confined deep-etched high-index contrast ridge waveguide lasers in the AlGaAs/GaAs material system, originally developed under prior NSF funding. Through improved lithography, etching, and oxidation, as well as the use of a novel super-large optical cavity heterostructure design, we fabricated for the first time ever a circularly-symmetric divergence beam edge-emitting laser. These devices provide single-spatial mode, high beam quality output powers on the order of 100+ mW compared to only ~5 mW achievable through competing circular-mode vertical cavity surface emitting laser (VCSEL) devices, with a near Gaussian output beam (M2<1.2). A provisional patent has been filed, and the PI is currently exploring technology transfer and commercialization activities for this invention in collaboration with the Notre Dame Idea Center.

The Broader impacts of this proposal included generally advancing photonic integrated circuit (PIC) technology to improve performance and reduce infrastructure costs of optical fiber communications networks, enabling the more widespread deployment of broadband optical communications in underserved areas. Secondary impacts included advancing III-V compound semiconductor oxidation technology, particularly as it is underutilized in the InP-based material system.  Education and outreach impacts included the utilization of REU supplemental funding to promote the integrated participation of undergraduate and graduate students from diverse backgrounds. Through a substantive unfunded collaboration with Tyndall National Institute in Ireland, this project will help foster the development of a more globally competitive STEM workforce.  Finally, advanced holography projects engaged 4 undergraduate research students in meaningful photonics-based research from their early years through graduation (over 15 total student semesters of projects). These students also helped refine and deliver a popular holography outreach workshop to ~75 high school physics students on each of 5 different occasions, promoting lasers and laser applications to a broad audience and stimulating greater interest in the STEM professions.
